subject: chemistry
title: Molecular and Empirical Formula MCQ Problems

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: What does the molecular formula of a compound represent?
options: The ratio of atoms in the simplest form
The actual number of atoms of each element in a molecule
The percentage composition of the compound
problems.hint: It tells the exact number of each type of atom in one molecule.
problems.detailed: The molecular formula shows the actual number of atoms of each element in a molecule. For example, glucose has a molecular formula of C6H12O6.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: How is the molecular formula related to the empirical formula?
options: The molecular formula is always smaller than the empirical formula
The molecular formula is a whole-number multiple of the empirical formula
problems.hint: The empirical formula shows the simplest whole-number ratio of atoms, while the molecular formula tells you the actual number of each atom present in a molecule.
problems.detailed: The molecular formula represents the true composition of a single molecule, giving the exact number of atoms of each element. It is related to the empirical formula by a whole-number multiplier (n). For example, the empirical formula \(\ce{CH2O}\) shows the simplest ratio of C:H:O as 1:2:1. If n = 6, then the molecular formula is \(\ce{C6H12O6}\), meaning each molecule actually has 6 carbons, 12 hydrogens, and 6 oxygens.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: If a compound has an empirical formula \(\ce{CH2}\) and a molecular mass of 42 g/mol, what is its molecular formula?
problems.hint: Find the molar mass of the empirical formula and compare with the molecular mass.
problems.detailed: The molar mass of \(\ce{CH2} = 12 + 2 = 14\) g/mol. Divide molecular mass (42) by 14 = 3. So the molecular formula is \((\ce{CH2}) \times 3 = \ce{C3H6}\).

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Which of the following statements about empirical and molecular formulas is correct?
options: The empirical formula can never be the same as the molecular formula
The molecular formula only shows the ratio of atoms
The empirical formula represents the simplest ratio of atoms in a compound
The molecular formula always has smaller numbers than the empirical formula
problems.hint: Think of the 'simplest whole-number ratio' definition.
problems.detailed: The empirical formula gives the simplest whole-number ratio of atoms in a compound, while the molecular formula gives the actual number of atoms.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: A compound has an empirical formula of \(\ce{CH2O}\) and a molecular formula of \(\ce{C6H12O6}\). What is the multiplying factor (n)?
problems.hint: Compare the subscripts of atoms in the molecular formula to the empirical formula.
problems.detailed: The empirical formula is \(\ce{CH2O}\). To get from \(\ce{CH2O}\) to \(\ce{C6H12O6}\), each subscript is multiplied by 6. Thus, the factor n = 6.
